pros: GSU as an entity is a great organization to work for. Benefits, (hybrid) remote work opportunities, and PTO/sick leave are good. The quality of one’s experience here is heavily dependent upon the department in which they work.
cons: Do not work in the Office of Admissions if you value your sanity, well-being, work/life balance, and opportunity to advance within the field of higher education. This office has incredibly an high turnover rate, and for good reason. The departmental leadership is incredibly unsupportive of its employees in every way you can imagine. If you’re looking for a position that will over work and under pay you, this one’s for you. They will actively stand in the way of you acquiring positions outside of the office, and you can’t trust any of them to serve as a trusted reference. The more I network, the more I discover that my experiences with this office are not even remotely unique. If I knew what I know now, I would have never accepted a position within this office.

review_title: RUN from the Office of Marketing & Communications!!!!
pros:
Beautiful campus, awesome President, friendly environment.
Busy environment and great networking throughout the University. Lots of opportunity to become involved.
cons:
Nepotism, poor department management, unqualified individuals in senior positions. 
It's sad when you have an amazingly talented team and the leadership is so unqualified that even HR can do nothing to assist them. When you have to train and retrain senior management on how to manage a small staff you clearly have hired the wrong person. The M&C department continues to lose qualified individuals left and right because of management and everyone (executive management) just looks the other way. Especially when you have other executives asking if management is bi-polar, or has multiple personalities. If you don't mind working in a toxic environment where you are called into your boss' office and questioned on why you don't like them because you didn't ask how they were doing when they were on crutches, then this is the place for you. If you enjoy hearing about your manager (or lack thereof) and their relationships, then this is the place for you. Also, if you don't mind constantly working with HR and filing formal complaints, then this is absolutely the place for you. This department has lost 9 employees in the last year and a half. Retention tells you a lot.

review_title: Good opportunity for short term growth, but low pay and area makes it unappealing for long term career
pros:
- Good learning opportunity in large sized, growing higher education institution
- Town is decent sized and close enough to Savannah, GA to make living there okay for a short enough period of time
- Nice campus, with a smaller feel, despite its growth. Some departments and colleges are growing fast, which allows for room for professionals and staff to grow
- Over all, there is a good amount of campus life and activities to provide professionals with real opportunities to engage and implement change/new ideas
- Because of the likelihood of turnover, there is room to grow for those willing/determined to stay here.
cons:
- It's such a small area. Unless you are somewhat local, it's not an appealing place to want to stay for very long. It ultimately serves as a stepping stone for many to go elsewhere
- Some departments more than others are drowning in politics, and local area professionals who are determined to stay there long term, but are not nearly as invested in the students, as they are in their egos
- Much like many higher ed institutions, there is a mix of very competent, qualified people; and many also that have risen because they never left, or knew someone there
-  This is a very Southern town, so to those not local it may be a real culture shock -- it's not unwelcoming, but it does take some adjustment

pros:
Laid back environment at times
EASY WORK, EASY MONEY
The full time custodian workers are cool to work with and let you do your own thing

If you want a job that pays 8.50 /hr for 16-24 hours a week while taking classes then I'd suggest this job. It's easy money with a laid back weekend shift.  However the week shift is a different story.
cons:
The supervisors are REALLY strict
On your feet for the entire shift (unless you hide in a closet)
The management and other higher ups don't really show you respect because you're a student

Since the shift for student workers is weekend only don't expect to party all weekend. The shift schedule is 8am-5pm. At 8:01 you're late. They're really strict with the clock in and out times. Another downside is that you're expected to clean the ENTIRE shift even after you've cleaned the building, which can be done in 2-3 hours. So basically, you have to pantomime cleaning in front of the cameras so that you don't get in trouble.

review_title: Awesome Experience Working as a Tutor of Student Athletes
pros: The student athletes are FANTASTIC to work with and always have a great attitude. The students have a desire to succeed and treat the tutors with a great amount of respect, not seen by many general students.
cons: The times available to tutor can be challenging to work around a school schedule. They will try to be flexible, but often times certain times of the day are slow because of athletic practices, classes, etc. Also, it is challenging to get a lot of hours in each week, so reliable hours are not possible week in and week out. Sometimes, students will not show for their appointment and that is a loss of planned working hours.

pros: It's a great place way to get your rent paid for if you're having a really tough time finding employment in the Statesboro, Ga area with how much competition their is for jobs. They'll just about hire you on spot just for being interested. Hiring crew is really nice and will do what they can to get you the job.
cons: Management is horrible. Lower level managers don't care about the employees and deal with working with many micro-managers who could care less about the fact that you're a college student. I was pushed to take this position as the area has a large lack of jobs but I just about wish I would've just been broke due to the horrible leadership I experienced working there.

pros: I was a student worker at GSU for 4 out of my 5 years there. They were very accommodating when I needed to leave early to study or complete homework, for meetings, or anything school related. I worked in 2 different places on campus and they were both fun environments that allowed me to gain valuable real-world experience as well. Any time the job stressed me out, I was able to let my manager know and they helped me out. They knew we were in school full-time and had other commitments as well.
cons: Working with the ADP system was annoying, if you clocked in a few minutes too late you weren't paid for the full hour, and you were limited to hours per week (also a good thing though). If you were coming from class across campus or had to leave for class, it might have messed with your hours.

review_title: CEO, the President is Great Leader
pros: Our President Dr. Keel came to us a few years ago with a rich and solid academic background. He is an leading Researcher, a dynamic Leader  in Science. I am very proud of him for his future vision, for his tireless, energetic, youthful, and fearless endeavors that have brought promising growth as well as reputation for GSU.
cons:
None, however should carefully consider hiring good and qualified chairs that listen to, care and communicate with their faculty. The chairs must have at least a record of doing substantial RESEARCH works. 

How can such an important chair in position lead a successful department to run without a decent research background?

review_title: Great People, great opportunity, great team
pros: I worked as a graduate assistant, teaching classes and doing research. It was a great place to gain some real world experience and some valuable life skills.  As the pay was my scholarship for graduate school and a monthly installation -- the pay was good that it payed for my schooling which was a large amount but the monthly payment was low, but better than nothing.  Great group of people and a southern charm that is very comforting and inviting.  Teachers and instructors are well qualified and very helpful. Departments are run very well and by good people.
cons: Statesboro is a fun little town, but small, and if you are teaching you will see students everywhere.

pros: It was a way to earn money while going to school, met some good people that I am still friends with to this day. Other than that there isnt anything good to be said about it.
cons: The pay for student workers is horrible, and in my position the people that I had to deal with at the school were jerks for the most part, I guess they were upset that one day they would probably be working for some of us. Most of the job was a downside to be completely honest. I wouldnt go back to work there, but thats just me.

review_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in the Chemistry Department
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Statesboro, GA
pros: I enjoyed my flexible work schedule. Overall, most of the professors in the department are friendly and easy to work with, so that makes working in the lab a good experience. Preparing for lab is important for all labs to go smoothly; this means spending time before lab reviewing materials and preparing yourself for any questions that students may ask.
cons: Some of the professors in the department may have different expectations/rules for their lab, so making sure that you both have a clear understanding of what is expected is important. Working with college students can be difficult at times, especially when they do not read the lab manual beforehand. Patience and preparation is key.

review_title: Student view of working at GSU
pros:
Great place for students to work while in college.  Allowed me to better understand aspects of my degree while helping other students.

I have gotten to work on some amazing projects and have been introduced to many great people.

Working with your professors while you are an undergraduate to a great way to gain key experiance beyond the classroom.
cons:
It is a public university so you do have to go through what seems like ten people and tons of paperwork to get anything done. Takes forever to get any payroll or human resources information changed or fixed if something is wrong.

School is rapidly expanding, it does seem like you are very insignificant sometimes.

review_title: Great place to live, not so great to work
pros: Students are great. Statesboro is an awesome little town. Great colleagues. I would love to live there, if I didn't have to have a job there.
cons: No stability. No job security. Loads of money going into Admin and Student Life, not so much going to pay the people who are teaching.

review_title: Good but top heavy with Administrators
pros: Overall a good environment.  There are opportunities to go back to school and yet still have your job.  Benefits are good and overall the people here are nice.
cons: Rather top heavy in the salary department.  Anyone who manages to become a director without an education makes money and the staff below that have such low salaries.  Any upward mobility is near impossible.  You have to know the right people and if you are an outsider, forget it.

review_title: Toxic environment and ethically challenged Professor
pros: Beautiful campus,  great student activities on campus and sports
cons: low pay, no research opportunities, narrow scope of research projects often given to the preferred students, masters level students and undergraduate students given priority over doctoral students.  Lies regarding what you could expect when working for the university. The position can be very demanding in duties that are  unrelated to the process of learning or teaching (the goal of your job).  The bulk of time is spent on useless activities or doing the work of the professor leaving little room for professional development. Save yourself some time and get real job because at the end all you will get is a letter of recommendation.

review_title: Good Starter Job, Low Pay, No Raises.
pros: Good place to start your career. Good Benefits. Beautiful campus.
cons: Slow to change and therefore, easy to outgrow.  Small-town mindset even at the university. The pay is on the lower-end of the spectrum for IT professionals, so all of the more-experienced employees usually get lured elsewhere. Lack of experienced employees prevents innovation and growth and doesn't allow for new employees to learn through a seasoned mentor. There are no pay raises. Must play heavy politics in order to advance. Workload can be heavy at times. Must deal with pretentious professor egos occasionally.

pros:

2) The pay rate is above the standard (also, gets wage increase), being said benefits are under par.
3) NOT a constant workload.
4) Secured position as long as you decide to stay with the school system.
cons:
1)  Could interfere with your social life, as sometimes you get called on your days off.
2)  NOT a constant workload also means, one day you could be grading 50+ tests, and assisting for 3 classes, but the next 3 days, you're absolutely free.

pros: Helps you to learn about other leadership roles on campus, workshops provided that allow you to grow professionally and personally, you learn to work with a team.
cons: The new contracts are updated to where you cannot hold another position on campus, whether it is paid or unpaid and I believe that stifles the potential and caliber of students that apply/work in the positions.

pros: The minimum pay is about 23000 for any job on campus and the people are all friendly.

cons: You can't work more than 50 hours in a pay period. I assume it's because 15 hours is typical course load for a college student and 25 hours of work a week would mean 40 hours every week which is a full time job.

cons: There have been changes to the university/campuses since the merger, which have made the environment/voice feel inconsistent over the past few years. Academic positions can have blurred work-life balance lines. Class sizes have been increasing as well for profitability.
